newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai copper ends limit-down on LME losses.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai copper ends limit-down on LME losses.

text.p: Shanghai copper futures ended limit-down across the board on Wednesday on heavy overnight losses on the London Metal Exchange (LME), traders said.
The most actively traded October 1997 contract ended at an intraday low of 22,280 yuan ($2,686) per tonne, losing 710 yuan. It opened at 22,430 and hit a high of 22,490 yuan per tonne.
July fell 640 to 21,890, August 640 to 22,030, September 680 to 22,190, November 710 to 22,340, December 710 to 22,330 yuan.
Combined volume rose to 111,055 tonnes from 50,380 tonnes.
Copper opened sharply lower and fell further until all contracts closed at the limit-down level.
On the LME, three months copper last traded at $2,437 a tonne, down $74 from Monday's close, after touching a five-week low of $2,430 a tonne.

LME traders said the failure of the market to convincingly pierce $2,600 earlier in the month, a narrowing in the spread, a few small warehouse stock increases and the approaching summer slow-down all combined to take the heat out of the buy side.
Traders in London said copper looked set to tumble to $2,350 if prices breached $2,400 on Wednesday.
Shanghai traders said these losses destroyed the confidence of local investors who have seen prices fall in the previous two sessions.
"Large amounts of stop-loss selling orders poured into the market on Wednesday, accelerating the downward trend," a Shanghai trader said.
"Market sentiment was extremely pessimistic with long position holders eventually giving up the territory they had dominated for a long period," he said.
The physical price in the Shanghai area plunged to the 22,000/100 yuan level in late Wednesdady, down from 22,600 on Tuesday due to heavy futures losses, traders said.
Traders said technical charts indicated a continued downward trend despite the downside trading of the past three days.
"A mid- and long-term downward trend seems to have taken shape though copper is likely to rebound slightly from time to time in between," a second traders said.
"The next support will be at the 20,000 yuan level."
Aluminium futures also ended limit-down.
July fell 390 to 13,510, August 280 to 13,630, September 410 to 13,690, October 460 to 14,020 and November 460 to 14,160 yuan per tonne.
Combined volume rose to 1,600 tonnes from 1,050 tonnes.
